title.narrative: Pro-Poor Planning Of Climate Resilience In Marginalized Neighborhoods

description.narrative:
The main purpose of the project is to support cities and UN member states to:
§ Improve climate resilience in selected marginalized neighborhoods,
The Purpose is to be understood within the context of ongoing city-wide climate resilience and resilience planning efforts. In other words, while the emphasis of the present Project is on neighborhood-level work – and thus primarily focused on building climate resilience through ‘hard and soft' measures, the project approach is only complete if those neighborhood actions are complimented by efforts to integrate those actions into city-wide efforts. Thus, we will seek to implement the Project in cities that are currently receiving relevant city-wide assistance from other UN-Habitat projects – ideally CCCI, PSUP and CRPP (to be confirmed) - that the present Project can complement.
The purpose of the project is therefore to achieve an integrated approach, covering three important dimensions of climate resilience planning:
Improve neighborhood-scale resilience planning, including (in all or some pilot locations) increased access to basic urban services, and thus addressing and building resilience through, and of, the physical environment. Those ‘hard' measures are to be complimented by an innovative participatory approach, Community-based Resilience (CBA), to build the resilience also of the people residing in those deprived locations. Through community engagement in the respective project locations, either using existing community structures (preferred) or creating community structures for the purpose of resilience building. The project will employ a participatory approach, implementing lessons from PSUP, in order to carry out the neighborhood vulnerability assessments and resilience planning exercises, and in order to link the community planning to the city wide planning processes, and by that empowered the urban poor to plan and take climate action. The third dimension to improve the resilience of marginalized neighborhoods is to integrate the neighborhood-scale efforts into city-wide planning and climate resilience action – and thus – to a certain extend – bring those effort into the formal city-wide system.
We will achieve this purpose in part through developing and testing new tools for pro-poor climate resilience planning. This will draw on several bodies of experience at UN-Habitat and in the broader development community. Firstly, UN-Habitat's Cities and Climate Change Initiative (CCCI), supported by Sida and others, has developed tools for assessing city-wide vulnerability to the impacts of climate change. Additionally CCCI has supported poor neighborhoods that are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change within the context of broader, city-wide efforts, for example, in: (i) the vulnerable Guet Ndar neighborhood of low-lying St. Louis, Senegal, where UN-Habitat helped the city to build adaptive capcity in vulnerable coastal communities and mobilized fund to relocate the highly vulnerable poor families; and (ii) the poor, flood-prone neighborhood of Bwaise in Kampala, Uganda, where intensive neighborhood efforts complemented development of a proposed city-wide strategy for integrated flood risk management. Resilience work in Mozambique – in part carried out under CCCI – has resulted in measurable and lasting resilience of vulnerable communities through the provision of resilient Infrastructure, coupled with community engagement, capacity development and training on resilience. Other experiences from Mozambique indicate that early involvement of vulnerable communities in planning and mapping can help adequately identify risks and vulnerabilities and thus improves the quality of interventions in adaptation to in coastal neighborhoods.
Secondly, UN-Habitat's Participatory Slum Upgrading Programme (PSUP) has developed solid methodologies related to in-situ slum upgrading. PSUP assessment methodologies, which already touch on climate change as well as other relevant cross-cutting issues such as human rights and gender, can be built on. Moreover, to the degree that the Project will be implemented in PSUP countries/cities, it can draw upon PSUP's network of national and local governments, communities and other stakeholders.
Thirdly UN-Habitat's Urban Basic Services Branch has undertaken pilot projects in marginalized neighborhoods as part of broader, city- or even nation-wide approaches to improve basic service provision. Fourthly, pilot cities have gained experience from participating in the City Resilience Profiling Programme of the Risk Reduction and Rehabilitation Branch. And finally the Global Land Tool Network (ULLGB) and others have argued persuasively that strengthening security of tenure represents a fundamental approach to building resilience.
